answers.text: large boulders that carve long scratches in the bedrock

qas.question: What can scientists deduct from the direction of the striations?

answers.text: lines of crescent-shape depressions in the rock underlying a glacier
abrasion when boulders in the glacier are repeatedly caught and released

qas.question: What is formed when glaciers lack boulders?
What helps scientists determine the speed of a glacier?
What is formed when glaciers crush boulders?

context: <b4_0><b5_0>Glacial abrasion<b5_0/><b4_0/> is commonly characterized by glacial striations. Glaciers produce these when they contain <a0_0>large boulders that carve long scratches in the bedrock<a0_0/>. By mapping <b6_0>the direction of the striations,<b6_0/> researchers can determine the <a1_0>direction of the glacier's movement<a1_0/>. Similar to striations are <b7_0>chatter marks<b7_0/>, <a2_0>lines of crescent-shape depressions in the rock underlying a glacier<a2_0/>. They are formed by <a3_0>abrasion when boulders in the glacier are repeatedly caught and released<a3_0/> as they are dragged along the bedrock.
